thread.title: New Zealand dominates Australia in debut international fistball match
thread.title_full: New Zealand dominates Australia in debut international fistball match

author: Christopher Reive
title: New Zealand dominates Australia in debut international fistball match

organizations.name: new zealand fistball association blase dowall

text:
New Zealand dominates Australia in debut international fistball match CHRISTOPHER REIVE Last updated 12:14, February 7 2017 DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
New Zealand women's fistball team captain Vikki Buston (left), and President of the New Zealand Fistball Association Blase Dowall. 
It might be a new sport in New Zealand, but the national women's fistball team have already trumped their counterparts from across the ditch. 
The men's and women's New Zealand fistball teams, the Fistferns, travelled to Geelong, Australia at the weekend, each playing a three-match series against the Australian teams for the Trans-Tasman Fistball Championship. 
The women's side stunned the Australians, taking a comfortable 3-0 series victory, winning 4-0, 4-1, 4-1. 
New Zealand Fistball Association President and women's coach Blase Dowall said the side were very impressive as they took out their first ever international matches. 
READ MORE: 
"To see them do that, they played very good fistball and really dominated. We were excited to know we would be bringing home some silverware. 
"We were pretty thrilled. We didn't think it would necessarily happen at the first tournament." 
The men's side fought well, but were unable to get the better of the Australian side, going down 2-1 in the series. 
"Every set was close, like 11-8 or 11-9. It was just a case of a little more experience needed." Ad Feedback 
Dowall said the tournament was a fantastic experience and it really hit everyone in the team when they lined up against the Green and Gold. 
He said it also provided an opportunity to see how our national teams matched up against a country with a bit more experience in the sport. 
"If we went over there and got smashed we'd know we have a lot more work to do. 
"The way we competed, there's no reason we can't go on and work toward the World Championships in the next few years." 
Dowall said since Stuff's first story on the sport in mid-January, he had received a lot of interest in people from around the country looking to get involved in the sport. 
He said with such positive signs coming out of their first international matches, the plan now would be to keep things going and hopefully see the sport played outside of the Canterbury region - where the entire New Zealand team were based. 
"I've been in touch with people in places like Auckland, Wellington and Taranaki asking about how they can get involved. 
"The last thing we want to do is to have this experience then see the sport fade away. We want to see it continue to grow." - Stuff
